Interesting question Ron.   I myself have a Nobuiye with that hexagonal des=
ign.    It is not well known or often discussed, but I have heard that Nobu=
iye for several years had a significant clandestine relationship with a tur=
tle.  I hope this helps.   Cheers, Bob  PS, sorry but couldn't resist the o=
pportunity for some levity.  B

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Ron H=
artmann" <swords@...> wrote:
>
> Hi All - 
> 
> Thought I'd through this ou=
t for discussion...
> 
> The tortuous shell pattern (also referred to as si=
mply "hexigan" motif) is found on many of the Nobuiye revival made tsuba --=
 often, tosho tsuba -- of shinshin-to times. Looking at examples of Nobuiye=
 work, this motif does frequently appear on his tsuba. Has anyone ever foun=
d reference to WHY this motif was so often used by Nobuiye? Does it relate =
to something that was particularly meaningful to Nobuiye? Does anyone ever =
recall reading anything on this? It would seem doubtful that it was used si=
mply because it was a pleasing pattern to adorn tsuba. 
> 
> Ron
> STL
>
